contextId.occurrenceNote: Both "The time" and "the day" refer to the time when God will punish the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "Israel's punishment will happen very soon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The time is coming; the day has come close

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The repetition emphasizes the surety of Yahweh's promise to bring the exiles back to the land of Israel. Alternate translation: "I will bring you back from all of the nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I will gather you from the peoples, and assemble you from the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each of these phrases have similar meanings and describes the people as obeying what Yahweh has commanded them to do. They are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: they will walk in my statutes, they will carry out my decrees and do them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: "when I cause them to separate from each other and live in different nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: when I scatter them among the nations and disperse them throughout the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases are both ways the people of Israel are saying Ezekiel's warnings will not happen in their lifetime but will happen far in the future. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The vision that he sees is for many days from now, and he prophesies of far off times

contextId.occurrenceNote: Barley is a grain used to make bread and the word "crumb" is a small amount of bread. Both phrases are small amounts of food and are used to emphasize how small the payment was to the prophetesses. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: handfuls of barley and crumbs of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to talking about what will happen in the future. Alternate translation: "continue to make false predictions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: have false visions or continue to make predictions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases are ways to tell the people of Israel to stop worshiping idols. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Repent and turn away from your idols! Turn back your faces from all your abominations

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases repeat the thought of a man dying because of his sin to express that it was his fault and the fault of no one else. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: dies because of them ... die in the iniquity that he has done

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks Ezekiel the same question twice in order to secure Ezekiel's commitment to pronounce the judgement. Alternate translation: "Are you ready to pronounce judgment on them, son of man?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you judge them? Will you judge, son of man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. See how you translated this in [Ezekiel 12:15](../12/15.md). Alternate translation: "cause them to separate from each other and live in different nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: scatter them among the nations and disperse them among the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will bring his people back from all of the nations to which he had scattered them. See how you translated this in [Ezekiel 20:34](../20/34.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: bring you out from the peoples and gather you out of the countries

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to the place where the two roads meet. Alternate translation: "at the crossroads" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: at the crossroads, at the junction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Ezekiel 12:15](../12/15.md). Alternate translation: "So I will cause them to separate from each other and live in different nations"(See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: So I will scatter you among the nations and disperse you through the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the violence that the princes practice. Alternate translation: "They murder people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: They pour out blood and destroy life

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means basically the same thing as the previous phrase and emphasizes the immoral behavior of the two young women. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "there men fondled their virgin nipples" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: their virgin nipples were fondled there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to a person who is laughed at and criticized because of their foolish behavior. Derision is mocking or ridiculing something or someone. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: a laughingstock ... a subject for derision

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Ezekiel is not to cry about his wife dying. Alternate translation: "you must not mourn nor weep" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you must not mourn nor weep, and your tears must not flow

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will completely destroy the people of Ammon so that they are no longer a nation. Alternate translation: "I will completely destroy you so that you are no longer a nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I will cut you off from the peoples ... make you perish from among the countries

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "plunder your riches" and "loot your merchandise" mean about the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: They will plunder your riches and loot your merchandise

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines are similar in meaning and emphasize the response of the surrounding people to the destruction of Tyre. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Now the coasts tremble on the day of your downfall. The islands in the sea are terrified, because you are no longer in your place

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. See how you translated similar phrases in [Ezekiel 12:15](../12/15.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: scatter Egypt among the nations and disperse them among the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. See how you translated similar phrases in [Ezekiel 12:15](../12/15.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: scatter Egypt among the nations and disperse them through the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Ezekiel 12:15](../12/15.md). Alternate translation: "I caused them to separate and live in separate lands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I scattered them among the nations; they were dispersed through the lands
